title: How to Find the MAC Address of Your Computer

steps.title: Open the Command Prompt
steps.content: Open the Command Prompt on your PC. You can use this method on any version of Windows, including Windows 10, 8.1, 7, and earlier. Open the Windows Search bar by pressing Windows key + S . Type Command into the search bar. Click Command Prompt in the search results.

steps.title: Type ipconfig /all at the prompt and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type ipconfig /all at the prompt and press ↵ Enter . This displays a bunch of network information in the Command Prompt window. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Locate the network adapter for which you want to find the MAC address.
steps.content: Locate the network adapter for which you want to find the MAC address. Each adapter has a name that describes the type of adapter it is—for example, Wireless LAN adapter Wi-Fi is your Wi-Fi connection, while Ethernet adapter is your Ethernet (wired) network card.

steps.title: Find the MAC address next to "Physical Address."
steps.content: Find the MAC address next to "Physical Address." It's the series of letters and numbers that looks like this: 1A-2B-3C-D4-E5-F6. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Connect to a network
steps.content: Connect to a network . For example, if you want to find the MAC address of your Wi-Fi network adapter, connect to Wi-Fi now.

steps.title: Click the network icon .
steps.content: Click the network icon . This is the network icon near the clock, which is usually at the bottom-right corner of the screen. [3] X Research source If you're connected to Wi-Fi, it'll be a wireless symbol, which looks like a cone made of curved lines. If you're connected through a wired connection, you'll see a computer with an ethernet cable. Depending on your connection type, the icon could also be a white globe. If you don't see an icon that looks like any of these, click the Windows menu, select Settings , and then click Network & Internet .

steps.title: Click Properties on your connection.
steps.content: Click Properties on your connection. You should see this link right below the active connection. If you got to your connection via your Settings, click the button that says Properties in the right panel.

steps.title: Scroll down to the “Properties” section.
steps.content: Scroll down to the “Properties” section. It's the final section in the window.

steps.title: Find the MAC address next to "Physical address (MAC)."
steps.content: Find the MAC address next to "Physical address (MAC)." It's the series of letters and numbers that looks like this: 1A-2B-3C-D4-E5-F6.

steps.title: Connect to a network.
steps.content: Connect to a network. For example, if you want to find the MAC address of your Wi-Fi network adapter, connect to Wi-Fi now.

steps.title: Open your System Preferences.
steps.content: Open your System Preferences. It'll be in the Apple menu, which is at the upper-left corner of the screen. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Network icon.
steps.content: Click the Network icon. It's the globe icon in your System Preferences. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Select Wi-Fi or Ethernet in the left panel.
steps.content: Select Wi-Fi or Ethernet in the left panel. If you want to find the MAC address for your wireless card, select Wi-Fi . If you have a wired connection to the internet, choose Ethernet .

steps.title: Click the Advanced button.
steps.content: Click the Advanced button. You'll see this in the lower-right corner of the window. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Hardware tab.
steps.content: Click the Hardware tab. It's the last tab in the upper-right corner of the window. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Find the MAC address.
steps.content: Find the MAC address. It's the series of letters and numbers that looks like this: 1A:2B:3C:D4:E5:F6.

steps.title: Open a terminal window.
steps.content: Open a terminal window . You can usually do this by pressing Ctrl + Alt + T on your keyboard, or by clicking the Terminal icon in your launcher.

steps.title: Type sudo ifconfig and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type sudo ifconfig and press ↵ Enter . Enter your password if prompted to do so.

steps.title: Find your MAC address next to "HWaddr."
steps.content: Find your MAC address next to "HWaddr." Scroll until you find your network connection (the primary ethernet card is labeled eth0 , and the wireless card typically begins with a "w"). The MAC address for each device appears next to "HWaddr" and looks something like this: 1A:2B:3C:D4:E5:F6. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Open your iPhone or iPad's Settings .
steps.content: Open your iPhone or iPad's Settings . It's the gray gear icon on your home screen or in your App Library. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Tap General.
steps.content: Tap General . It's in the third group of settings. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Tap About.
steps.content: Tap About . This is right at the top of the General menu. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Scroll down to "Wi-Fi Address."
steps.content: Scroll down to "Wi-Fi Address." Your iPhone or iPad's MAC address appears here, and looks something like this: 1A:2B:3C:D4:E5:F6

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings .
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings . It's the gear icon in your app list. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Tap About phone or About device.
steps.content: Tap About phone or About device . The option you see will vary depending on your Android.

steps.title: Tap Status.
steps.content: Tap Status . Depending on your Android, you may need to tap Status to find your MAC address. Other Androids may display the MAC address right on the About page.

steps.title: Find your MAC address.
steps.content: Find your MAC address. Whether you find it on the About page or the Status page, your MAC address will look something like this: 1A:2B:3C:D4:E5:F6. [13] X Research source If you're using Android 10 or later, your Android is configured to randomly choose different MAC addresses when connecting to Wi-Fi. If you need to supply a MAC address to someone so they can let it through a router (or for any other reason), you can disable this feature in Settings > Network & Internet (or Connections ) > Wi-Fi . Just tap the gear icon next to the connection, tap MAC address type , and choose Use phone MAC .

steps.title: Click the clock.
steps.content: Click the clock. You'll usually see this at the bottom-right corner of the desktop. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Select your Wi-Fi network.
steps.content: Select your Wi-Fi network. This displays the current connection.

steps.title: Click the small "i" in a circle.
steps.content: Click the small "i" in a circle. It's at the top of the box.

steps.title: Find the MAC address next to "Wi-Fi."
steps.content: Find the MAC address next to "Wi-Fi." It's the series of letters and numbers that looks like this: 1A:2B:3C:D4:E5:F6.

steps.title: Start your PlayStation 5 without a disc.
steps.content: Start your PlayStation 5 without a disc. If your PS5 is already on, restart it without the game or movie inside.

steps.title: Select the gear icon.
steps.content: Select the gear icon. It's at the upper-right corner of the home screen. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Select System on the menu.
steps.content: Select System on the menu. It's the cube icon.

steps.title: Select Console Information.
steps.content: Select Console Information . This appears at the top of the menu.

steps.title: Find your MAC address.
steps.content: Find your MAC address. Your Wi-Fi MAC address is prefaced with "MAC Address (Wi-Fi)," while your wired MAC address starts with "MAC Address (LAN Cable)."

steps.title: Start your PlayStation 4 without a disc.
steps.content: Start your PlayStation 4 without a disc. If your PS4 is already on, restart it without the game or movie inside. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Select Settings.
steps.content: Select Settings . It's the icon that looks like a toolbox.

steps.title: Scroll down and select System.
steps.content: Scroll down and select System . It's near the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Select System Information.
steps.content: Select System Information . It's at the top of the menu.

steps.title: Find your MAC address.
steps.content: Find your MAC address. Your Wi-Fi MAC address is prefaced with "MAC Address (Wi-Fi)," while your wired MAC address starts with "MAC Address (LAN Cable)."

steps.title: Start your PlayStation 3 without a disc.
steps.content: Start your PlayStation 3 without a disc. If your PS3 is already on, restart it without the game or movie inside.

steps.title: Select Settings.
steps.content: Select Settings . You can press the X to select this and all remaining options.

steps.title: Select Network Settings.
steps.content: Select Network Settings . Information about your network settings will appear.

steps.title: Select Settings & Connection Status List.
steps.content: Select Settings & Connection Status List . Now you'll see information about your current connection.

steps.title: Find the MAC address under "MAC Address."
steps.content: Find the MAC address under "MAC Address." It's the series of letters and numbers that looks like this: 1A:2B:3C:D4:E5:F6.

steps.title: Start up your Switch to the Home menu.
steps.content: Start up your Switch to the Home menu.

steps.title: Select System Settings on the menu.
steps.content: Select System Settings on the menu. It's the gear icon in the icon row at the bottom of the screen. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Scroll down and select Internet.
steps.content: Scroll down and select Internet . It's in the left panel.

steps.title: Find the MAC address next to "System MAC Address."
steps.content: Find the MAC address next to "System MAC Address." It'll be in the right panel.

steps.title: Start your Wii without a disc inside.
steps.content: Start your Wii without a disc inside. If there's already a disc inside, just remove it and restart your Wii.

steps.title: Press the A button on your Wii Remote.
steps.content: Press the A button on your Wii Remote. This takes you to the main menu. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Select Wii.
steps.content: Select Wii . It's at the bottom-left corner.

steps.title: Select Wii Settings.
steps.content: Select Wii Settings . It's the wrench icon on the right side.

steps.title: Scroll to page two of the Settings screen.
steps.content: Scroll to page two of the Settings screen. You can do this by selecting the right-pointing arrow.

steps.title: Select Internet.
steps.content: Select Internet . It's near the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Select Console Information.
steps.content: Select Console Information .

steps.title: Find the MAC address at the top of the screen.
steps.content: Find the MAC address at the top of the screen. It's the series of letters and numbers that looks like this: 1A:2B:3C:D4:E5:F6.

steps.title: Press the X button on your controller.
steps.content: Press the X button on your controller. This opens a menu.

steps.title: Select Profile & System.
steps.content: Select Profile & System . It's the first icon at the upper-left corner.

steps.title: Select Settings.
steps.content: Select Settings . It's the gear icon toward the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Select the General tab.
steps.content: Select the General tab. It's the first tab in the left panel.

steps.title: Select Network settings.
steps.content: Select Network settings . This is the option with a wireless symbol and a gear in the right panel.

steps.title: Select Advanced settings.
steps.content: Select Advanced settings . It's toward the bottom-right corner of the screen.

steps.title: Find the MAC addresses.
steps.content: Find the MAC addresses. The MAC address of your Wi-Fi card will appear next to "Wireless MAC," while your wired LAN card's MAC address appears next to "Wired MAC."

steps.title: Go to My Xbox on the Xbox Dashboard.
steps.content: Go to My Xbox on the Xbox Dashboard. This opens the menu. [19] X Research source If you haven't already connected to a network, you'll want to do so before you continue.

steps.title: Select Settings on the menu.
steps.content: Select Settings on the menu. It's the option with a gear icon. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Select Network on the menu.
steps.content: Select Network on the menu. This displays some more settings.

steps.title: Select Advanced Settings.
steps.content: Select Advanced Settings .

steps.title: Find the MAC addresses.
steps.content: Find the MAC addresses. The MAC address of your Wi-Fi card will appear next to "Wireless MAC," while your wired LAN card's MAC address appears next to "Wired MAC."

steps.title: Go to My Xbox in the Xbox Dashboard.
steps.content: Go to My Xbox in the Xbox Dashboard. A menu will expand. [21] X Research source If you haven't already connected to a network, you'll want to do so before you continue. It can be any network at all—you'll just need some type of connection so the MAC address will appear. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Select your network name and choose Configure Network.
steps.content: Select your network name and choose Configure Network .

steps.title: Select the Additional Settings tab.
steps.content: Select the Additional Settings tab. It's at the top-right corner.

steps.title: Select Advanced Settings.
steps.content: Select Advanced Settings . It's right above "Restore to Factory Defaults."

steps.title: Find the MAC address in the left panel.
steps.content: Find the MAC address in the left panel. The MAC address is the 12-character number at the bottom of the left panel. You won't see any colons or dashes between the pairs of letters and numbers.
